<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 339, 317]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Probability & Statistics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[777, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 326, 905, 342]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>

You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 270, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 364, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 866, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 856, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 213, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 698]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 729, 714]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
Rachel has three coins. The first coin is biased so that the probability of obtaining a head when it is thrown is \(\frac{1}{3}\). The second coin is biased so that the probability of obtaining a head when it is thrown is \(\frac{1}{4}\). The third coin is fair.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
Rachel throws the three coins at the same time. The random variable \(X\) is the number of **tails** that she obtains.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 177, 920, 196]]<|/det|>
Draw up the probability distribution table for \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 177, 920, 196]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 853, 89]]<|/det|>
In Millford, \(70\%\) of the residents own a bicycle. A random sample of 160 residents is selected.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximation to find the probability that more than 120 of these residents own a bicycle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 137]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
Vehicles approaching a certain road junction from Bromley must go either left, right or straight on. Over time, it is known that \(30\%\) turn left, \(25\%\) turn right and \(45\%\) go straight on. The driver of each vehicle chooses a direction independently of all other drivers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the next three vehicles approaching this junction from Bromley all go in different directions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 395, 146, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that, from the vehicles approaching this junction from Bromley today, the 1st vehicle to go left is before the 9th vehicle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 413, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 658, 144, 677]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 658, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that, from the vehicles approaching this junction from Bromley today, the 2nd vehicle to go left is the 7th vehicle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 676, 920, 695]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 92, 87]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 69, 920, 104]]<|/det|> The times taken, \(t\) minutes, by 300 students to travel to Hollowton College are recorded. The results are summarised in the table below. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 115, 895, 168]]<|/det|>
Time (t minutes)\(t\leqslant 10\)\(t\leqslant 20\)\(t\leqslant 30\)\(t\leqslant 40\)\(t\leqslant 60\)\(t\leqslant 90\)
Cumulative frequency3486142208265300
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 144, 198]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 180, 759, 198]]<|/det|> On the grid, draw a cumulative frequency graph to illustrate this information. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 205, 794, 758]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 800, 146, 819]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 800, 920, 819]]<|/det|> 120 students take more than \(k\) minutes to travel to college. Use your graph to estimate the value of \(k\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 814, 920, 833]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Calculate estimates of the mean and standard deviation of the times taken to travel to college by the 300 students.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways in which the 10 letters in the word AMALGAMATE can be arranged so that there is an M at the beginning, an M at the end and no As are together. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 650, 180, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 648, 920, 682]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways in which the 10 letters in the word AMALGAMATE can be arranged with exactly 3 letters between the two Ms. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 365, 690, 384]]<|/det|>
Five letters are selected from the 10 letters in the word AMALGAMATE.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 144, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 396, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different selections in which the five letters include at least one M and at least two As.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 414, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 460, 432, 477]]<|/det|>
10 adult kestrels are selected at random.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 490, 144, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 489, 722, 508]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that fewer than 3 have masses greater than \(0.202 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
